title: Co-working, co-living trend extends to hotels
text:
A new boutique hotel with 60 small rooms will open in Sydney's inner city suburb of Pyrmont in early 2020, following a growing trend of pocket-sized hotel rooms with high-end communal spaces to maximise returns in the face of high land costs.

The property at 131-133 Murray Street, within walking distance of Darling Harbour, is being developed by prominent Malaysian developer Tan Boon Lee and will become the first Cititel X hotel in Australia, part of a network of hotels already operating in Malaysia.

Mr Tan, who bought the property in 2016 for $11 million, hails from one of the biggest developer families in Malaysia, which locally has been involved in the restoration of Queen Victoria Building and Strand Arcade.

Renders of the Cititel X hotel which will open in February 2020.

The idea behind the hotel is to get the maximum number of rooms out of the property and compensate with a "co-living" area and garden terrace on the ground floor where guests can spend time working or socialising or cooking a meal in the communal kitchen. The average room size is between 14 and 18 sq m.

Similar business models are already in operation locally, including the Doma Group's Little National hotel in Canberra, which has 120 compact rooms encouraging guests to spend time in the communal library and lounge area.
description: There are two main reasons for the growing trend towards smaller room typologies.
